Bar 1903: Inside Tallahassee's first library-turned bar News Sports Entertainment Opinion Email Us Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals MONEY Bar 1903: A toast to the next chapter of Tallahassee's first library TaMaryn Waters Tallahassee Democrat More than 100 years ago, a tall sturdy bookshelf held hundreds of books. It is now replaced with¬†a mirrored display case of bourbon, gin, rum and cognac. The Walker Library, the first in Tallahassee, has begun¬†a new chapter as Bar 1903 . The¬†name pays homage to its history and stands as a throwback to old Tallahassee, when women wore Victorian fluted skirts and frilly long-neck blouses alongside men in top hats and overcoats. It was a different time, roughly 80 years after Tallahassee became the state's Capitol. Years before, Gov. David S. Walker (in office 1865-68) had shepherded the effort that launched with two small reading areas upstairs. Skip to today, it's one of the few historic¬†buildings still open to the public, thanks to its induction into downtown¬†nightlife. From original heart pine floors and columns, antique sconces and the "library" sign outside, much of it appears frozen in time. Bar operator Jesse Edmunds of Seven Hills Hospitality Group was perfectly fine running his other popular¬†restaurants and bars: El Cocinero on Tennessee Street, and The Hawthorn Bistro & Bakery and Liberty Bar on North Monroe Street in Midtown. But a¬†series of serendipitous events occurred ‚Äî the property owner buying the lot for $350,000 in May, coming into Edmunds' restaurants as a customer, posting pictures of the property and not knowing what to do with it and Edmunds' wife seeing the post ‚Äî¬†it all seemed like destiny. Edmunds was curious about the space, one of only¬†65 Leon County properties listed on the National Register of Historic Places.¬†He took an initial meeting about the¬†2,300-square-foot former library sitting on roughly a third of an acre. Once inside, it was love at first sight. ‚ÄúIt was not something I was looking for or wanted to do,‚Äù Edmunds confessed. ‚ÄúBut as soon as I walked in and looked up. I was like, ‚ÄòOh crap. Here we go. Four.‚Äô ‚Äù The old space has character, like something in the pages once housed along the walls. Up high, the ceiling has¬†intricate woodwork akin to the era.¬†None of the windows are the same height, a quirky feature Edmunds found charming. Going upstairs, the narrow staircase could easily give someone vertigo and the low balcony rails are more ornate than functional. He decided upstairs would be closed off for customers and used for¬†storage. According to a 2016 Tallahassee Democrat article , the Walker Library served the community from 1903 to 1956, when the library moved into the basement of the Columns, an antebellum mansion two blocks west on Park Avenue (a building since relocated to Duval Street and Park Avenue, where it is the home of the James Madison Institute). Restoration on the former library spanned four months and included a new bar, walls for the restrooms, new paint and wood rejuvenation. Bar 1903 opened Feb. 7 and, within five minutes, 50 customers¬†lined up to be among the first inside. It seats up to only 36 customers at a time and the high demand resulted in a two-hour waiting list for the rest of the night. In fact, every night has been slammed, Edmunds said, with the exception of Monday. ‚ÄúWhen we say we‚Äôre 36 seats, it‚Äôs not because we are trying to be pretentious or tight. It‚Äôs because that‚Äôs the back wall,‚Äù said Edmunds, pointing to the fireplace featuring a portrait of Walker and large windows overlooking South Calhoun Street. ‚ÄúPeople come and don‚Äôt understand they can‚Äôt just stand at the bar." Tapas and shareable foods, ranging from $7 to $20, are served within the 16-page, leather bound menu of food, spirits and cocktails. Edmunds uses his other businesses for production, preparation and storage for the food served at Bar 1903. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost like a stationary food truck in a way,‚Äù Edmunds explained. The first page of the menu reads ‚ÄúAthenaeum‚Äù ‚Äî an ‚Äúinstitution for the promotion of literary or scientific learning.‚Äù It features drinks grouped by years, such as "Pre 1880" with the Manhattan and the John Collins and "1919-1933" with a Hanky Panky and a Side Car. Edmunds said the gin and tonics selection has been wildly popular. Aside from specialty drinks, it's stirring nostalgia for residents who remember coming to Walker Library as children. It's likely to be added as a featured attraction for Tallahassee's tourism. More: From books to booze: Historic downtown Tallahassee library building will next become bar ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to see Bar 1903 opening¬†as the latest example of the recent growth of top-notch restaurants and nightlife options within easy walking distance of several hotels, bringing increased foot traffic and energy to downtown," said Kerri¬†Post, who heads Leon County Tourism, also known as Visit Tallahassee. After the Democrat's initial story about the bar, several social media comments wrongfully assumed taxpayer money was spent to bring the bar to fruition, Edmunds said. "People assume we got tons of handouts from the city, (that) we‚Äôre heavily subsidized like The Edison,‚Äù Edmunds said. ‚ÄúWe have gotten not a dime. I funded this project. The landlord is private. We have done this. We haven‚Äôt had a cent of taxpayer money ‚Ä¶ This is us doing this for Tallahassee.‚Äù Contact TaMaryn Waters at tlwaters@tallahassee.com or follow @TaMarynWaters on Twitter. Search now Home / About / Who We Are The voice of Canada‚Äôs legal profession The Canadian Bar Association champions Canada‚Äôs legal profession and the rule of law in Canada. We are the largest association for legal professionals in the country, representing over 40,000 lawyers, judges, notaries, academics and students. We connect our members to the people, knowledge and skills they need to successfully practice law. We offer a strong, unified voice and promote fair justice systems, effective law reform, wellness and equity. We are the legal profession‚Äôs go-to source for high-quality legal training and information. Explore what we do and how we work Our Vision and Mission remove_circle_outline add_circle_outline We are the essential ally and advocate of the legal profession and guardian of the rule of law in Canada. Our members are passionate about their association and the good it brings to their lives and to the world. Staff and volunteers are inspired to exceed members‚Äô expectations every day. Our mission is to: Improve the law and the administration of justice Improve and promote access to justice Promote equity in the legal profession and in the justice system Improve and promote the knowledge, skills, ethical standards and well-being of members of the legal profession Promote the interests of CBA members and represent the legal profession nationally and internationally How We Work remove_circle_outline add_circle_outline The CBA has a National Office in Ottawa, branches in every province and territory , and an in-house counsel division called the CBA In-House Lawyers . Through the work of the CBA Executive, Board of Directors, Leadership Forum, Committees, Sections and staff at the national and branch levels, we lobby the government on important legal issues, protect the profession‚Äôs core values and actively engage with Canada‚Äôs legal community. We offer high-quality professional development programs, conferences and events. Our publications, practice tools, resources and podcasts offer insights into global and national trends affecting your work. Learn how CBA is governed Our History remove_circle_outline add_circle_outline We have been championing Canadian lawyers and Canadian law since 1896. The Canadian Bar Association has existed in its present form since 1914. The association was incorporated by a Special Act of Parliament on April 15, 1921. Check out delightful food and cocktails at intimate Bar 1903 - Tallahassee Table Dining & drinking in Florida's Capital City and beyond‚Ä¶ Home About Calendar Features Reviews Chefs Farming Contact Us Search Features Check out delightful food and cocktails at intimate Bar 1903 by Tallahassee Table March 2, 2022 written by Tallahassee Table March 2, 2022 5.7K From library to libations: Historic setting pairs top-notch menu and superb drink menu Bar 1903 has to be one of the most enchanting spots in Tallahassee. The historic building was Tallahassee‚Äôs first library, lovingly renovated by Jesse Edmunds, owner of Liberty Bar , El Cocinero and The Hawthorn Bistro & Bakery . It‚Äôs a beautiful setting, thankfully spared. My husband and I went to Bar 1903 on a recent Friday night and since we were there about 5 p.m., we were able to snag a table without a wait.You may have heard about the superb cocktail menu at Bar 1903, but the food menu is another reason to visit this charming venue. We had the grilled honey-roasted butternut squash bruschetta and it was perfect for the season. The toasted baguette was topped with the squash, arugula, whipped black pepper goat cheese, a white balsamic reduction and toasted pistachios ‚Äì fantastic. Andouille and crawfish mac and cheese is one of the dishes you‚Äôll want to share at Bar 1903. Photo / Tallahassee Table My husband and I also devoured an excellent beef and brie sandwich plus a dish of andouille and crawfish mac and cheese that was ultra rich. Comfort food with a zingy twist. Deviled eggs and pecan stuffed figs are two other treats. As for the cocktails, there‚Äôs a holiday drink menu available in December, including a Gingerbread Old-Fashioned with Old Forrester, Pimms, Gingerbread syrup and Angostura Cocao Bitters; warm, homemade apple cider with your choice of Calvados, Old Forester Bourbon and Plantation Dark Rum; I‚Äôm Dreaming Of ‚Ä¶ with St. Augustine Vodka, White Chocolate Liqueur and Peppermint whipped cream along with A Hallmark Original featuring Chai-spiced Bacoo Rum, coconut milk, evaporated milk, chestnut praline syrup and a whole egg. You‚Äôll find modern cocktails with garnishes like a sliced of blood orange or drinks created more than a decade ago. Photo / Tallahassee Table Also, check out the trademark cocktail menu that‚Äôs divided into time periods, starting with pre-1880, including drinks that have now become standard: a Manhattan, an Old-Fashioned, Sazerac.Bar 1903 is a lovely choice normally whether for a date night or a gathering of friends, but it‚Äôs even prettier now, decked out for the holidays. Cheers! Here‚Äôs my initial story on Bar 1903 for more background. Jesse Edmunds wasn‚Äôt in the market for another new business.¬† But then his wife, Briana, persuaded him to check out a vacant building downtown. He reluctantly agreed because, well, it wasn‚Äôt just any building. Tallahassee‚Äôs first library, spared from demolition, was waiting to be given a new life. ‚ÄúI looked up and saw the ceiling and said, ‚ÄòDamn it!‚Äô ‚Äú said Edmunds ‚Äî owner of Liberty Bar and Restaurant, El Cocinero and The Hawthorn Bistro & Bakery. ‚ÄúIt hit me like a ton of bricks.‚Äù He knew then that he wanted to take on this new project: transforming the historic David S. Walker Library, built in 1903, and saved from the construction of the Ballard Building right next door. On Friday, Feb. 7, after months of work by Edmunds and his team, Seven Hills Hospitality Group, the former library was reborn as Bar 1903. A space that once nurtured the minds of its patrons will now tempt their palates with fun small plates and dozens of classic cocktails in a lovely setting. About 50 customers were lined up at the door when the place opened at 4:30 p.m. Friday. But the place only has room for 36. My husband and I and our friends tried to get in on Saturday night but it was filled to capacity and we didn‚Äôt want to wait. I came back on Tuesday to meet with Edmunds to get a better look and hear more about his vision for Bar 1903. While there are modern accents, the former library has an intimate feel. There‚Äôs really only one main room, which is elegant and understated, with a few nooks for more¬† privacy. It‚Äôs decorated in soft, neutral colors with lots of woodwork and black furniture. A portrait of David S. Walker hangs over the fireplace. A narrow staircase by the bar leads to a second floor, a skinny walkway flanked by wood that encircles the main room like a VIP balcony at an opera. Sadly it‚Äôs not workable for serving the public. ‚ÄúLook how narrow it is,‚Äù said Edmunds. And there‚Äôs only one staircase to get up and down in case of fire. It sure adds charm to the room, though. The challenge here, at least during prime time ‚Äî is getting a seat. Bar 1903 operates like this: If the room is filled to capacity, the host will keep your place and take your cell number to contact you when seating opens up (there‚Äôs no way to know whether that will be a short time or hours later though waits tend to be 30 to 40 minutes). Once you‚Äôre contacted, you have 15 minutes to come back and claim your seat. A historic building finds new life in downtown Tallahassee . Photo / Tallahassee Democrat There‚Äôs no place for standing or waiting unless you want to take a stroll. The Chain of Parks is across the street. About 400 to 500 patrons stopped by Bar 1903 over the weekend and ‚Äúwe seated 190 of them,‚Äù said Edmunds.¬† ‚ÄúMost had to go somewhere else‚Äù ‚Äî at least until space opened, if they indeed wanted to come back. Bar 1903 is the latest downtown venture, joining the upscale restaurants Il Lusso and Saveur, the retro lounge/restaurant Rootstock and Eve on Adams, the new rooftop cocktail lounge perched above the 16-floor DoubleTree by Hilton. These places didn‚Äôt exist two years ago, but there‚Äôs room for all of them, said Edmunds. Some customers who couldn‚Äôt get into Bar 1903 went to Jesse‚Äôs other venues, Liberty and El Cocinero, and a good many had dinner and/or drinks at the other downtown destinations. ‚ÄúAll of us won,‚Äù said Edmunds. Bar 1903 isn‚Äôt competing with full-service fine dining menus. Edmunds features small plates ‚Äî charcuterie boards, bites like deviled eggs and crab toast, sandwiches and desserts. The star here is the drink menu, which offers House Cocktails, like the Demon Seal (with Bacoo 12-year rum, chai spiced maple syrup and smoked cinnamon), the Juniper Tree (with Fords Gin, Yellow Chartreuse and strawberry dust) and Heavy Metal Queen (St. Augustine vodka, rose and vanilla syrup). There‚Äôs a separate page for Gin & Tonics that‚Äôs ‚Äúsuper cool,‚Äù said Edmunds.‚ÄùI was never a gin drinker before I experienced this. It‚Äôs a complex and beautiful spirit.‚Äù Following the House Cocktails, the drinks menu is divided into time periods, starting with pre-1880, including drinks that have now become standard: a Manhattan, an Old-Fashioned, Sazerac. ‚ÄúThere wasn‚Äôt any Internet then, but you can see what trends were like on the East Coast and the West Coast and what spirits were popular,‚Äù Edmunds said. ‚ÄúThere was a lot of commonality.‚Äù Other timelines are 1880-1919, 1919-1933, 1933-1950, 1950-1980, 1980-2000, 200-Now and beer and wine.¬† Except for Miller High Life and Michelob Ultra, Bar 1903 carries beer from Florida breweries: Proof and Deep (Tallahassee), Oyster City Brewing (Apalachicola), Cigar City (Tampa) and 3 Daughters Brewing (St. Petersburg). Aside from developing the bar and menu, Edmunds and his team were also involved in doing much of the work. ‚ÄúI can look around and be proud,‚Äù he said. Edmunds built the bar with red oak and chinkapin wood he obtained from Quincy. He hand-milled the wood, creating 650 slabs that he fashioned into a herringbone pattern used for the top of the bar. It‚Äôs polished to a natural sheen using Odie‚Äôs Oil, developed by James Tinghitella in Sopchoppy. He also built the back of the bar and the bathrooms. Photo: Bar 1903, as work was being done to transform the library. As for that gorgeous high ceiling, it needed to have mold mitigation work. ‚ÄúWe hired a specialty window washer who hand-mopped it using a 40-foot extension pole from the middle of the room,‚Äù said Edmunds. That ceiling, and its skylight, are stunning. ‚ÄúA building like this is rare and hard to find,‚Äù said Edmunds. ‚ÄúThe stars were aligned.‚Äù Bar 1903 is 209 E. Park Ave.; 850-354-9739. It‚Äôs open from 4:30 p.m. to midnight Monday to Thursday and 4:30 to 2 a.m. Friday to Saturday.
